Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Biochemical Mechanism of Oomycete RXLR Effector Binding to PI3P
Award.AbstractNarration:
Beneficial and pathogenic microbes have major impacts on plants, animals, and humans, and on natural and managed ecosystems. Microbes that establish close interactions with plants and animals use a wide diversity of molecules to suppress or negotiate with their hosts' immune systems, including effector proteins that can enter host cells to directly re-program metabolism. Some microbes cause destructive diseases of plants, while other species provide major benefits. In all cases, it is poorly understood how effector proteins from microbes cross the membrane surrounding host cells to enter the cell interior. Although substantial progress has been made on this question, the technical challenges of the studies have slowed progress and have resulted in conflicting findings and controversy. This project will focus on solving the most severe technical challenges in this area, namely the question of how effector proteins interact with host membrane lipids, in order to reduce controversy and advance the field.

More specifically, the investigators will carry out detailed biochemical experiments aimed at resolving conflicting findings regarding the binding of oomycete effectors to the lipid phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate. The work will focus on the two effectors from oomycetes for which the most structural and biochemical information is currently available, namely Phytophthora sojae Avh5 and Phytophthora capsici Avr3a4.

The project has three objectives.

1. Refine the effector protein expression and purification methods in order to identify the precise details required for obtaining preparations of the proteins that are active in host cell entry and lipid binding.

2. Identify at a very detailed level the biochemical conditions required to reproducibly observe binding of the effectors to phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate.

3. In order to identify residues involved in binding, use precise and quantifiable methods to assay lipid binding by the purified effectors and their mutants, including Surface Plasmon Resonance and Isothermal Calorimetry, and circular dichroism spectroscopy.

In addition to advancing understanding of how microbes interact with plants, animals and humans, the broader impacts of this project will include the training of a postdoctoral scholar and several undergraduate researchers, and the mentoring of a junior investigator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanisms by which virulence proteins (effectors) secreted by eukaryotic microbes enter hosts are still poorly understood. This question is important for fundamental understanding of how microbial and macrobial ecosystems interact. This project is centered on the mechanisms by which effectors produced by the oomycete pathogen of soybean, Phytophthora, sojae enter plant cells. In particular, the project is focused on the mechanism that one particular P. sojae effector protein, Avr1b, uses to bind to the lipid membrane surrounding plant cells. Previous work had indicated that Avr1b bound to a specific lipid, phosphatidylinositol-3-phosphate (PI3P), in order to enter plant cells, but a number of questions remained to be answered. The goal of this project was to confirm and extend this finding.

 

The results of the project confirmed that Avr1b protein could bind tightly to PI3P, even when it was produced in a different microbe species, Pichia pastoris, which is a yeast species commonly used for producing large amounts of proteins for laboratory study. The project results also uncovered two novel properties of Avr1b.  First it was discovered that Avr1b was trimmed at the N-terminus, presumably by proteases, after it was secreted from Phytophthora sojae; but this trimming however was not required for the protein to enter plant cells. Second, it was discovered that Avr1b was glycosylated (i.e. by attachment of sugar molecules) at multiple sites on the protein, when it was produced in Pichia pastoris or Phytophthora sojae. Some of the glycosylation occurred near the N-terminal sequences (RXLR) required for PI3P-binding and cell entry, but PI3P-binding was not affected. Glycosylation may protect the protein from excessive trimming.

 

The results of the project will improve understanding of how oomycete effectors enter plant cells, and may improve understanding of how microbe proteins more generally enter plant and animal cells. This improved understanding will assist management of plant diseases and pests in the contexts of agriculture, horticulture, forestry, and natural resources conservation. It will also assist understanding of how microbial populations establish stable and beneficial interactions with plants, animals and humans in the context of health and environmental preservation.
